article.headline: BYU 76, Washington State 68
article.story: SPOKANE, Wash. (AP) -- After opening at home with a loss to Loyola Marymount of the West Coast Conference, Brigham Young coach Dave Rose had some trepidation about going on the road to play Washington State of the Pacific-10. But Brigham Young jumped to a quick lead and Brock Reichner scored a career-high 18 points as BYU beat Washington State 76-68 on Tuesday night at the Spokane Arena. BYU (1-1) got its first win under Rose, a longtime assistant to Steve Cleveland who took over when Cleveland jumped to Fresno State. The victory broke a string of three consecutive losses to WSU. "We made a lot of progress in the last three days in trying to become a team," Rose said, of how his team improved from the 83-71 loss to Loyola Marymount. "We played a lot tougher." Reichner, who is married to Rose's daughter, kept killing Washington State rallies with key baskets in only the third start of his career. "He has us believing in each other," Reichner said, adding "he's my father-in-law on Thanksgiving, today he's my coach." "Brock is our lone senior and our staff made the conscious decision that we were going to build our team around our toughest guy," Rose said. Brigham Young shot 55.3 percent in the game, and made 9-of-18 3-pointers. Washington State coach Dick Bennett saw his team slide in the other direction after opening with a 31-point win over UC-Riverside. The Cougars (1-1) fell behind 8-2 early and never took the lead, although they managed to tie the game once midway through the first half. "We needed stops tonight and we were unable to get them," Bennett said. "It was a really bad start and any time you come out not ready to play, you don't deserve to win," said WSU guard Derrick Low, who had 13 points and seven assists. Washington State played without three of its top seven players, who are out with injuries, Bennett said. Robbie Cowgill and Rodney Edgerson should be out for a few more weeks, and Daven Harmeling may be lost for the season, Bennett said. Junior college transfer Ivory Clark of WSU led all scorers with 23 points, shooting 8-for-10 from the field. Washington State shot 54.8 percent as a team. But BYU held Josh Akognon, who had 22 points in the season opener, to 5 points. "Derrick and Josh didn't have many good looks," Bennett said. After WSU trailed 34-30 at halftime, Clark scored seven of his team's first 15 points in the second half, and the Cougars closed to 51-48 on Low's 3-pointer with 8:28 left. But Fernando Malaman's 3-pointer closed a quick 7-2 run to give BYU a 58-50 lead. Malaman finished with 14 points, a career high. The teams traded baskets and WSU edged closer. But Reichner's 3-pointer lifted BYU to a 68-61 lead with 3:25 left and his team was able to fend off WSU the rest of the way. In the first half, Washington State did not make its first field goal -- on a turnaround jumper by Aron Baynes --until there was 16:25 left. Washington State eventually went on an 11-4 run and tied the score at 20 on Kyle Weaver's 3-pointer with 6:36 left in the half. Consecutive 3-pointers by Reichner and Lee Cummard and a basket by Reichner gave BYU a 28-20 lead. Clark had 10 in the first half for Washington State, including seven in the final four minutes.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
